action_space.name: Therapeutic Alliance and Engagement
action_space.description: Therapist builds rapport, fosters trust, and encourages open communication to support collaboration throughout therapy.

goal.objective: Develop a strong, safe, and collaborative foundation for effective therapeutic work.

success_levels.ideal: Patient feels understood, safe, and motivated; participates actively and shares openly.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient expresses some willingness to engage, with moderate trust and participation.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient feels disconnected, mistrustful, or unengaged, blocking therapeutic progress.

goal.reward_hint: Patient expresses feeling understood, participates willingly, or references the strength of the alliance.

states: Patient expresses hesitancy, mistrust, or low engagement
Therapeutic relationship strains or ruptures emerge

micro_actions.name: Warm Greeting and Rapport-Building
micro_actions.description: Greet the patient warmly, express interest in their well-being, and acknowledge any initial concerns.

micro_actions.name: Validate and Reflect Patient Experience
micro_actions.description: Use empathic language and reflective listening to validate feelings and concerns.

micro_actions.name: Solicit Collaborative Input and Decision-Making
micro_actions.description: Invite patient input on goals, preferences, agenda, or session changes to foster equality.

micro_actions.name: Directly Invite Feedback on the Alliance
micro_actions.description: Ask for honest feedback about session quality, progress, or relational comfort.
states: When patient appears uncomfortable or disengaged

micro_actions.name: Normalize Hesitancy and Reduce Stigma
micro_actions.description: Acknowledge patient uncertainties as common to reduce shame or fear about the therapy process.

action_space.name: Psychoeducation and Therapy Orientation
action_space.description: Therapist explains CBT principles, session structure, dispels myths, and normalizes emotional and psychological experiences.

goal.objective: Increase patient understanding of CBT, foster engagement, and correct misconceptions.

success_levels.ideal: Patient accurately understands CBT concepts and rationale, feels reassured, and participates actively.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient shows basic understanding and reduced misconceptions, and is open to starting therapy.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient remains confused or resistant due to misunderstanding or stigma.

goal.reward_hint: Patient articulates CBT principles, expresses reduced shame or curiosity, and asks relevant questions.

states: Therapy is beginning or transitioning to a new focus
Patient is unfamiliar or uncertain about CBT/diagnosis
Misconceptions, stigma, shame, or anxiety about therapy are evident

micro_actions.name: Explain CBT Model and Treatment Structure
micro_actions.description: Describe CBT basics, session agenda, the therapist’s and patient’s roles, and therapy expectations using clear language.

micro_actions.name: Normalize Symptoms and Emotional Distress
micro_actions.description: Validate symptoms as common and understandable, reducing self-blame and stigma.

micro_actions.name: Debunk Myths and Address Misconceptions
micro_actions.description: Directly correct misconceptions or stigmatizing beliefs about mental health and therapy.

micro_actions.name: Invite Questions and Feedback
micro_actions.description: Ask the patient to share questions, concerns, or uncertainties about therapy or CBT.
states: Patient hesitates, appears confused, or expresses doubts

micro_actions.name: Reinforce Psychoeducation with Visuals or Handouts
micro_actions.description: Provide written summaries, diagrams, or recommended reading materials for further learning.

action_space.name: Assessment, Diagnosis, and Case Formulation
action_space.description: Therapist gathers information on symptoms, personal history, context, and risk to clarify presenting problems and form an individualized CBT case conceptualization.

goal.objective: Achieve a shared, clear understanding of patient’s difficulties and conceptual model to guide treatment.

success_levels.ideal: Comprehensive, collaboratively-developed formulation with clear targets for intervention.
success_levels.acceptable: Basic understanding of problems and relevant patterns sufficient to start planning.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Problems remain unclear, fragmented, or formulation is missing/inaccurate.

goal.reward_hint: Therapist and patient reference the formulation and agree on targets for intervention.

states: Symptoms or history are unclear or complex
When planning or revising treatment targets

micro_actions.name: Ask Targeted Assessment Questions
micro_actions.description: Ask direct questions about symptoms, impairment, triggers, risk, and comorbidities.

micro_actions.name: Elicit Narrative and Context
micro_actions.description: Invite patient to share key life events, background, and symptom course for context.

micro_actions.name: Administer and Review Standardized Measures
micro_actions.description: Use validated rating scales or questionnaires for diagnostic clarity and symptom tracking.

micro_actions.name: Collaboratively Review and Update Formulation
micro_actions.description: Summarize findings, review with patient for accuracy, and jointly adjust as treatment progresses.

micro_actions.name: Identify and Rate Mood, Thoughts, Emotions, Behaviors
micro_actions.description: Prompt patient to distinguish and rate severity of presenting experiences using scales and worksheets.

action_space.name: Agenda, Goal Setting, and Action Planning
action_space.description: Therapist and patient collaboratively set session agendas, prioritize treatment goals, and develop actionable plans for intervention.

goal.objective: Establish shared goals and clear session plans to organize and focus therapy.

success_levels.ideal: Patient and therapist agree on specific, measurable goals and action steps; work proceeds collaboratively.
success_levels.acceptable: Goals are moderately specific and session structure is present but may lack full clarity.
success_levels.unsuccessful: No clear goals or agenda; patient feels uninvolved or the plan is unfocused.

goal.reward_hint: Patient articulates and selects goals, actively participates in setting agenda and plans.

states: When motivation or direction is unclear

micro_actions.name: Initiate Agenda Setting and Goal Identification
micro_actions.description: Ask the patient what they wish to address, add clinical priorities, and confirm session agenda.

micro_actions.name: Elicit Patient's Preferences and Values
micro_actions.description: Invite patient to identify what changes they desire and what matters most.

micro_actions.name: Collaboratively Prioritize and Specify Goals
micro_actions.description: Discuss and select focus areas, translating goals into observable, measurable terms.

micro_actions.name: Record and Review Agenda/Goals
micro_actions.description: Write down chosen topics and confirm patient agreement; revisit progress at session end.

micro_actions.name: Facilitate Cost–Benefit and Motivation Discussion
micro_actions.description: Discuss pros and cons of pursuing goals or changes to enhance buy-in and clarify direction.

action_space.name: Cognitive Interventions: Identification and Restructuring
action_space.description: Therapist helps the patient identify automatic thoughts, cognitive distortions, and maladaptive beliefs, and uses Socratic techniques to challenge and modify them.

goal.objective: Reduce distress and maladaptive behaviors by restructuring dysfunctional cognitive patterns.

success_levels.ideal: Patient regularly identifies, evaluates, and modifies automatic thoughts and beliefs with increased cognitive flexibility.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient recognizes some patterns and engages in restructuring with therapist support.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient is unable or unwilling to identify or challenge problematic thoughts.

goal.reward_hint: Patient articulates automatic thoughts, participates in cognitive tasks, and verbalizes new perspectives.

states: Patient reports distressing emotions or behaviors tied to thoughts
Cognitive restructuring or belief modification phase
Persistent negative thinking or rigid beliefs present

micro_actions.name: Elicit and Record Automatic Thoughts
micro_actions.description: Prompt patient to identify and write down automatic thoughts in context, especially associated with strong emotion.

micro_actions.name: Identify and Categorize Cognitive Distortions
micro_actions.description: Guide patient in recognizing distortions (e.g., catastrophizing, all-or-nothing) in their thinking.

micro_actions.name: Use Socratic Questioning to Challenge Beliefs
micro_actions.description: Ask questions probing for evidence, alternative explanations, and validity of thoughts and beliefs.
states: Automatic thoughts or beliefs appear rigid or unhelpful

micro_actions.name: Facilitate Generation of Alternative Thoughts
micro_actions.description: Coach the patient to construct and write more adaptive, balanced thoughts and consider emotional impact.

micro_actions.name: Guide Ratings of Belief Strength and Mood Change
micro_actions.description: Ask patient to rate belief in automatic and alternative thoughts and note mood shifts.

micro_actions.name: Review and Troubleshoot Cognitive Restructuring
micro_actions.description: Re-examine process if no improvement, check for missing steps, and encourage further practice.

action_space.name: Core Beliefs and Schema Work
action_space.description: Therapist assists patient to identify, evaluate, and modify core beliefs and schemas underlying persistent difficulties.

goal.objective: Restructure negative core beliefs and build more flexible, adaptive self-concepts.

success_levels.ideal: Patient identifies and changes core beliefs, adopting healthier alternatives and demonstrating lasting change.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient becomes aware of core beliefs and starts practicing new perspectives.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Core beliefs remain unexamined or unchanged.

goal.reward_hint: Patient discusses core beliefs, practices new ones, and behavior reflects change.

states: Longstanding patterns traced to global beliefs
Later therapy stages focused on underlying schemas

micro_actions.name: Apply Downward Arrow Technique
micro_actions.description: Use recursive questioning to uncover deeper, core beliefs behind surface automatic thoughts.

micro_actions.name: Facilitate Core Belief Worksheet Completion
micro_actions.description: Help patient fill out structured exercises clarifying global beliefs and tracking their strength.

micro_actions.name: Solicit and Reinforce New Adaptive Beliefs
micro_actions.description: Encourage patient to articulate and practice more functional alternative core beliefs.

micro_actions.name: Support Behavioral Experiments for New Beliefs
micro_actions.description: Plan and conduct behavioral tests to gather evidence for or against core beliefs.

micro_actions.name: Prompt Regular Monitoring and Review
micro_actions.description: Instruct patient to rate beliefs periodically and reflect on supporting evidence and behavioral change.

action_space.name: Behavioral Activation, Experimentation, and Skills Training
action_space.description: Therapist uses graded activity scheduling, behavioral experiments, and skills training to reduce avoidance, increase adaptive behaviors, and improve functioning.

goal.objective: Decrease avoidance and increase positive behavior, learning, and coping skills.

success_levels.ideal: Patient completes planned experiments and activities, develops new skills, and benefits are generalized.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient attempts activities/experiments and practices some skills, with partial progress.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient avoids activities or fails to practice, resulting in persistent symptoms.

goal.reward_hint: Patient completes tasks, describes outcomes, and demonstrates skill use in session and daily life.

states: Symptoms related to inactivity, avoidance, or skill deficits
Patient is ready to test beliefs or build new behaviors

micro_actions.name: Collaboratively Design Behavioral Experiments and Activity Plans
micro_actions.description: Work with patient to specify activities or experiments, predict outcomes, and plan details including steps and timing.
states: When practical learning or activation is needed

micro_actions.name: Break Tasks Into Steps and Problem-Solve Barriers
micro_actions.description: Guide patient to break down complex actions and anticipate and address possible obstacles.

micro_actions.name: Model and Teach New Behavioral/Coping Skills
micro_actions.description: Demonstrate targeted skills, facilitate rehearsal, and provide feedback.

micro_actions.name: Prompt In-Session or Homework Skill Practice
micro_actions.description: Assign regular structured practice (e.g., relaxation, assertiveness, exposure, mindfulness).

micro_actions.name: Encourage Tracking and Reflection
micro_actions.description: Ask patient to record activity/mood, note obstacles, and reflect on enjoyment, mastery, or learning.

action_space.name: Exposure and Response Prevention
action_space.description: Therapist and patient collaboratively design and implement graded exposure to feared or avoided situations and guide prevention of safety behaviors.

goal.objective: Reduce avoidance and anxiety by increasing experiential learning and disconfirming maladaptive beliefs.

success_levels.ideal: Patient completes hierarchically graded exposures, reduces anxiety/avoidance, and acquires adaptive responses.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient attempts exposure tasks with some decrease in distress or avoidance.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient continues to avoid feared situations, uses safety behaviors, or increases anxiety.

goal.reward_hint: Patient completes and reflects on exposures and reports decreased distress or more adaptive functioning.

states: Patient presents with avoidance, anxiety, phobia, or OCD symptoms
When reducing avoidance or testing beliefs is needed

micro_actions.name: Develop Exposure Hierarchy
micro_actions.description: Work with patient to list feared situations, rate anxiety, and prioritize steps for exposure.

micro_actions.name: Assign and Guide Exposure Tasks
micro_actions.description: Facilitate planning, execution, and in-session or homework practice of exposure tasks.

micro_actions.name: Prompt Prediction and Outcome Review
micro_actions.description: Ask patient to predict outcomes of exposures, track expectation vs. reality, and debrief on results.

micro_actions.name: Monitor and Reduce Safety Behaviors
micro_actions.description: Identify and discourage the use of safety signals, avoidance, or rituals during exposure.

micro_actions.name: Provide Support and Encouragement During Exposure
micro_actions.description: Coach, normalize challenges, and reinforce progress as patient completes exposure steps.
states: Patient expresses distress or doubt during exposure

action_space.name: Skills Generalization, Homework, and Progress Review
action_space.description: Therapist assigns practice tasks between sessions, monitors progress, addresses obstacles, and reinforces skill development.

goal.objective: Generalize CBT skills to real-life situations and foster independent coping.

success_levels.ideal: Patient completes homework consistently, applies skills independently, and reports gains.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient attempts homework with therapist support and shows partial skill generalization.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient avoids or does not complete homework and skills do not generalize.

goal.reward_hint: Patient brings records/homework, reports skill use outside session, and discusses successes and challenges.

states: When monitoring application in daily life

micro_actions.name: Assign Clear, Specific Homework Tasks
micro_actions.description: Clearly communicate and document the activity, tracking, or skill practice to be done before the next session.

micro_actions.name: Review Homework Completion and Barriers
micro_actions.description: Discuss with patient what was completed, explore difficulties, and normalize problems with compliance.

micro_actions.name: Collaboratively Problem-Solve Obstacles
micro_actions.description: Brainstorm solutions for identified barriers, adapt assignments, and reinforce effort.

micro_actions.name: Provide Positive, Constructive Feedback
micro_actions.description: Acknowledge progress, reinforce skill use, and reframe setbacks as opportunities for learning.
states: On patient expression of effort or challenges

micro_actions.name: Model Mistake Normalization
micro_actions.description: Therapist shares examples of learning from mistakes to reduce shame or defensiveness about incomplete tasks.

action_space.name: Relapse Prevention and Termination Planning
action_space.description: Therapist and patient prepare for therapy ending by consolidating skills, anticipating risk, and developing maintenance plans.

goal.objective: Enable patient to sustain gains, prevent relapse, and apply skills independently post-therapy.

success_levels.ideal: Patient develops and practices a relapse prevention plan, maintains progress, and expresses readiness for independence.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient understands risks, uses basic strategies, and requires minimal reminders.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient is unprepared, lacks a plan, or regresses when therapy ends.

goal.reward_hint: Patient can articulate prevention strategies, self-monitor, and demonstrates flexible coping.

states: Patient is concerned about setbacks, relapse, or future risks

micro_actions.name: Review and Consolidate Skills and Progress
micro_actions.description: Summarize skills learned and areas of improvement, celebrating gains and identifying continued vulnerabilities.

micro_actions.name: Collaboratively Develop Relapse Prevention Plan
micro_actions.description: List likely triggers and warning signs, brainstorm coping strategies, and update a plan for future setbacks.

micro_actions.name: Practice Skills in High-Risk Scenarios
micro_actions.description: Rehearse and plan skill use for anticipated challenges using role-play or mental imagery.

micro_actions.name: Ensure Visibility of CBT Materials
micro_actions.description: Recommend patient keeps skills records and prevention plans easily accessible for reference.

micro_actions.name: Promote Use of Social Support
micro_actions.description: Encourage use of support systems and communication during setbacks as part of the plan.

action_space.name: Crisis Management and Safety Planning
action_space.description: Therapist directly addresses acutely increased risk (e.g., suicidality or emergency needs) through focused assessment, stabilization, and plan development.

goal.objective: Manage acute risk and ensure patient safety through rapid assessment, collaborative planning, and emergency intervention if needed.

success_levels.ideal: Risk is identified, managed actively, and safety is secured with a clear plan.
success_levels.acceptable: Risk is reduced or monitored; plans are in place for ongoing safety.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Risk persists or worsens; safety plan is absent or not followed.

goal.reward_hint: Patient follows safety plan, risk is reduced, or therapist takes appropriate emergency actions.

states: Patient reports suicidal ideation, self-harm risk, or acute emergency
Ongoing risk factors surface during treatment
Crisis or emergencies occur in session

micro_actions.name: Directly Assess Risk
micro_actions.description: Ask focused questions about suicidal intent, plans, means, or acute risk factors.

micro_actions.name: Develop and Review Safety/Coping Plan
micro_actions.description: Collaboratively create a safety plan, including coping steps, emergency contacts, and means restriction.

micro_actions.name: Monitor and Reassess Risk During Session
micro_actions.description: Check in regularly about ongoing emotional state and risk level; adapt plan as needed.

micro_actions.name: Initiate Emergency Procedures if Indicated
micro_actions.description: Contact support, emergency care, or arrange hospitalization if patient safety is at imminent risk.

micro_actions.name: Provide Emotional Support and Grounding
micro_actions.description: Use calming statements and grounding exercises to reduce acute distress.
states: Patient is highly anxious or agitated in crisis

action_space.name: Ongoing Progress Monitoring and Troubleshooting
action_space.description: Therapist regularly tracks symptom change, adapts interventions, and engages in collaborative problem-solving of obstacles and setbacks.

goal.objective: Ensure effective treatment by tracking progress, adjusting strategies, and resolving barriers.

success_levels.ideal: Symptoms and goals are tracked, obstacles are addressed, and treatment adapts to promote continuous improvement.
success_levels.acceptable: Progress is monitored; treatment adjustments are made for partial improvement.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Progress stalls or regresses without responsive troubleshooting.

goal.reward_hint: Documented progress, intervention changes, and specific problem-solving observed in therapy.

states: When symptoms do not improve as expected
Barriers to engagement, skill use, or homework occur

micro_actions.name: Review Symptoms, Ratings, and Observations
micro_actions.description: Discuss and clarify symptom ratings, behavior logs, and self-reported mood for discrepancies and progress.

micro_actions.name: Provide Constructive Feedback
micro_actions.description: Deliver feedback linking improvements or areas of change to treatment steps.

micro_actions.name: Troubleshoot Barriers to Treatment
micro_actions.description: Openly address problems such as avoidance, lack of motivation, hopelessness, or perfectionism.

micro_actions.name: Adapt Goals and Interventions
micro_actions.description: Collaboratively review and adjust goals or plans based on feedback and life changes.

micro_actions.name: Encourage Self-Validation and Strengths Focus
micro_actions.description: Prompt patient to note progress and reinforce small gains, building confidence.

conversation_states.Description: Content, frequency, and valence of patient’s spontaneous thoughts that drive emotional and behavioral responses. Used to identify maladaptive patterns and guide cognitive restructuring.
Underlying, deep-seated beliefs about self, others, or the world, including confidence and changes in these beliefs. Guides advanced CBT and cognitive restructuring.
Degree of conviction in target, alternative, and problematic cognitions, including automatic thoughts and core beliefs.
Current emotional state and its intensity, including shifts and predominant affect (e.g., anxiety, depression, anger, guilt).
Strength or severity of emotional responses or distress. Used to track intervention impact, risk, and session pacing.
Overall intensity and fluctuation of target psychiatric symptoms (e.g., depression, anxiety). Guides formulation and treatment.
Extent to which symptoms or behaviors interfere with social, occupational, educational, or daily functioning.
Type, presence, and frequency of faulty thinking patterns (e.g., catastrophizing, overgeneralization, black-and-white thinking). Informs cognitive restructuring.
Patient’s ability to identify, reflect on, and understand their own thoughts, emotions, and behavioral patterns.
Patient’s willingness, motivation, and openness to engage in change processes and new strategies.
Strength, quality, and trust in the working relationship between therapist and patient, including collaboration and conflict.
Patient’s activity, willingness, and collaboration during sessions and with treatment tasks.
Degree of completion, quality of engagement, and reflection with therapy homework, assignments, or behavioral experiments.
Presence, frequency, and reliance on avoidance and safety behaviors/rituals aimed at reducing perceived threat or distress.
Movement toward therapy/treatment goals, including behavioral activation, symptom reduction, and completion of tasks.
Presence, quality, and helpfulness of patient’s relationships, support network, and interpersonal connections.
Frequency and effectiveness of adaptive or maladaptive coping skills used to manage distress, including problem-solving and emotional regulation.
Influence of comorbid diagnoses or symptoms (e.g., depression, social anxiety, chronic pain, substance misuse) on session engagement and progress.

conversation_states.Variable Name: Relapse Risk and Early Warning Signs
conversation_states.Description: Presence and intensity of early warning signs or risk factors for relapse or deterioration. Used for monitoring and prevention.
Presence, intensity, and change in suicidal thoughts, intent, planning, and behaviors. Guides safety planning.
Internal and external barriers (practical, emotional, motivational, or situational) interfering with progress, engagement, or skill application.
Degree of shift in conviction or emotional response following behavioral experiments or corrective experiences.
Extent to which acquired cognitions and behaviors transfer to situations outside of session. Indicates real-world impact.
Self-reported or observed emotional discomfort or distress, including SUDs ratings. Used to inform safety and intervention selection.
Patient’s preparedness, willingness, and commitment to take action, explore new strategies, or participate in exposures/advanced interventions.
Therapist’s own emotional responses and their potential influence on the session.
Overall assessment of patient’s well-being and satisfaction with life, reflecting symptoms and functional impact.
Quality, onset, duration, and disruptions in sleep, including restfulness or insomnia.
Somatic symptoms related to mood or anxiety (e.g., sleep, appetite, energy, agitation).
Consideration of individual cultural, developmental, and identity factors relevant to therapy engagement and alliance.
Ability to retain, recall, and apply CBT concepts and skills, highlighting barriers and need for adaptations.
Whether patient’s attention is self-focused or externally directed. Guides intervention selection.
External circumstances or recent life events impacting engagement, such as trauma, financial stress, or loss.
Degree of agreement or discrepancy between therapist and patient on goals, analysis, and evidence.

nodes.description: Root node representing the individual receiving cognitive behavioral therapy.
Patient’s age, gender, cultural background, education, vocation, and social context.
Presenting complaints, symptom descriptions, and contextual/problem history.
Mental and physical health diagnoses, comorbidities, and longitudinal symptom profiles.
Relevant medical background, medication adherence, and physical health/disability details.
Family history of psychiatric, medical, and substance issues impacting the patient.
Developmental, childhood, family, social, educational, and critical life events or trauma.
Cultural, familial, religious, language, and developmental influences relevant to therapy.
Enduring beliefs and schemas about self, others, world; developmental origins and conviction strength.
Attitudes, rules, conditional assumptions derived from core beliefs.
Recurring spontaneous cognitions or negative automatic thoughts and their context and impact.
Unhelpful thinking styles, biases, and patterns across time.
Adaptive and maladaptive patterns including avoidance, approach, rituals, withdrawal, and safety behaviors.
Adaptive and maladaptive strategies used by the patient for regulation and distress management.
Patient’s identified strengths, assets, resilience, and available social/relationship supports.
Quality, rupture/repair cycles, engagement, compliance, feedback, and skill development in the therapy relationship.
Records of CBT interventions, exposures, behavioral experiments, and effectiveness/rationale.
Therapy homework and assignments history, adherence, completion, and outcome notes.
Acquisition and mastery of CBT skills and ability for independent use.
Scheduling of activities, mastery/pleasure ratings, and engagement/avoidance patterns.
Patterns of emotional, behavioral, and physiological responses including depression, anxiety, anger, shame, and mood tracking.
Situational, personal, or environmental triggers for symptoms, moods, and automatic thoughts.
Catalogue of specific safety, avoidance, and ritual behaviors, their context and frequency.
History and details of symptom episodes, relapses, setbacks, warning signs, and preventive strategies.
Key goals, values, motivation sources, and value-based behavioral patterns.
Problem-solving style, skill level, attempts, progress, and responses to setbacks.
Personality disorder features or relevant traits such as obsessiveness, perfectionism, or hostility.
Self-esteem, shame, self-worth, identity, and related beliefs and changes.
Typical physical reactions to emotional distress (e.g., agitation, withdrawal, somatic symptoms).
Patterns in diet, sleep, exercise, substance use, routines, and self-care.
Substance or behavioral addictions and compulsive behaviors.
Sleep patterns, quality, beliefs about sleep, and related behaviors.

nodes.type: Eating Disorder and Body Image Features
nodes.description: Disordered eating patterns, compensatory behaviors, body image concerns, and related beliefs.
Obsessional problems, compulsions, rituals, and related avoidance.
Antecedents, patterns, and consequences of anger and rumination.
History, timing, and sequence of trauma, loss, abuse, bullying, neglect, and associated impacts.
Role/involvement of significant others/family in support, rituals, or symptom maintenance.
Therapist’s observations, notes, reactions, and clinical assumptions about therapy process.
Functioning and impairment in social, academic, occupational, and daily living domains.
Scores and outcomes from standardized assessment and symptom measures over time.
Patient’s evolving insight, metacognition, and understanding of therapy and disorder.
Patient transference patterns and therapist’s countertransference reactions.

edges.source: Eating Disorder and Body Image Features
Eating Disorder and Body Image Features

cautions.negative_action: Rigid adherence to protocol or technique
cautions.description: Strictly following standardized procedures or one framework without adapting to patient context.
cautions.risk: Reduces effectiveness, may harm alliance, alienates or overwhelms patient.

cautions.negative_action: Ignoring or undermining therapeutic alliance
cautions.description: Neglecting collaborative relationship or empathy with the patient.
cautions.risk: Damages trust, reduces engagement and effectiveness.

cautions.negative_action: Forcing interventions or exposure before readiness
cautions.description: Pushing patients into experiments, exposure tasks, or new skills before consent or preparation.
cautions.risk: Causes distress, loss of trust, increases dropout and risk of harm.

cautions.negative_action: Dismissing, minimizing, or invalidating patient thoughts or emotions
cautions.description: Ignoring, downplaying, or criticizing patient emotional experiences or distress.
cautions.risk: Breaks trust and may worsen distress or lead to dropout.

cautions.negative_action: Allowing or reinforcing avoidance and safety behaviors
cautions.description: Permitting use of distraction, rituals, reassurance, or safety strategies during exposure or therapy.
cautions.risk: Maintains anxiety and maladaptive patterns, undermines therapeutic progress.

cautions.negative_action: Making uncollaborative assumptions about patient beliefs or readiness
cautions.description: Assuming patient beliefs or history without collaborative exploration.
cautions.risk: Leads to resistance, misunderstanding, reduced efficacy.

cautions.negative_action: Skipping planning, preparation, or debriefing for experiments
cautions.description: Failing to plan, reflect, or provide preparation and follow-up for behavioral or cognitive tasks.
cautions.risk: Limits learning, may increase distress, reduces quality of outcomes.

cautions.negative_action: Breaching confidentiality or professional boundaries
cautions.description: Disregarding privacy or ethical boundaries or sharing patient information inappropriately.
cautions.risk: Damages trust, alliance, and may have legal repercussions.

cautions.negative_action: Neglecting physical health or medical safety
cautions.description: Ignoring health risks, needed clearance, or safety in interventions; offering advice outside professional scope.
cautions.risk: Endangers patient, can result in harm or legal issues.

cautions.negative_action: Overwhelming the patient with excessive, complex, or unrealistic tasks
cautions.description: Assigning tasks or goals that are too difficult, packed, vague, or mismatched with patient readiness.
cautions.risk: Causes discouragement, avoidance, disengagement.

cautions.negative_action: Offering non-evidence-based or unproven interventions
cautions.description: Using untested, anecdotal, or outdated methods not supported by empirical research.
cautions.risk: Ineffective or harmful therapy outcomes.

cautions.negative_action: Invalidating accurate perceptions or real risks
cautions.description: Dismissing genuine negative events or minimizing physical, social, or emotional risks.
cautions.risk: Alienates patient, undermines safety, prevents adaptive coping.

cautions.negative_action: Focusing exclusively on cognition or behavior
cautions.description: Only targeting cognitive or behavioral aspects, neglecting emotions, context, or environmental factors.
cautions.risk: Limits efficacy and ignores core issues.

cautions.negative_action: Using authoritarian, didactic, or impersonal communication
cautions.description: Lecturing, persuading, or communicating in a top-down manner instead of guided discovery.
cautions.risk: Fosters resistance, inhibits alliance, reduces engagement.

cautions.negative_action: Assigning blame, shaming, or criticizing for symptoms or setbacks
cautions.description: Responding punitively or judgmentally to errors, failures, or lack of progress.
cautions.risk: Increases shame, undermines motivation, and engagement.

cautions.negative_action: Neglecting or improperly assessing suicide or self-harm risk
cautions.description: Failing to monitor, assess, or respond to signs of suicidality or self-harm.
cautions.risk: Serious patient safety threat, potential loss of life.

cautions.negative_action: Ignoring comorbid conditions or contextual factors
cautions.description: Neglecting physical health, substance use, trauma, or cultural/social background in treatment.
cautions.risk: Poor outcomes, alienates patient, misses core contributors.

cautions.negative_action: Proceeding before medical or psychiatric stabilization
cautions.description: Starting therapy with acute medical or psychiatric instability.
cautions.risk: Worsens condition or misses critical medical needs.

cautions.negative_action: Failing to track symptoms, progress, or relapse risk
cautions.description: Omitting symptom monitoring, progress tracking, or relapse prevention planning.
cautions.risk: Increases risk of deterioration and missed setbacks.

cautions.negative_action: Endorsing unrealistic expectations of rapid or total symptom elimination
cautions.description: Promising complete, instant relief from symptoms or minimizing plateaus/setbacks.
cautions.risk: Leads to disappointment, drop-out, and invalidates patient experience.

cautions.negative_action: Conflating therapist authority over patient's autonomy or physician's role
cautions.description: Imposing therapist’s views, dismissing patient agency, or contradicting medical guidance.
cautions.risk: Reduces collaboration, risks safety, erodes trust.

cautions.negative_action: Using stigmatizing language or labels
cautions.description: Labeling or pathologizing patients negatively or pejoratively.
cautions.risk: Damages self-esteem, increases stigma, blocks progress.

cautions.negative_action: Encouraging passive or superficial efforts
cautions.description: Accepting half-hearted attempts, lack of engagement, or letting patient be passive in process.
cautions.risk: Reduces skill development, fosters dependence, impairs outcomes.

cautions.negative_action: Forcing or rushing cognitive challenging or belief change
cautions.description: Challenging beliefs, guided discovery, or core schemas before rapport or readiness.
cautions.risk: Increases resistance, distress, or dropout.

cautions.negative_action: Failing to tailor interventions to individual background, history, or education
cautions.description: Using generic or irrelevant interventions that disregard patient’s history, strengths, culture, or learning style.
cautions.risk: Reduces motivation, engagement, relevance, and efficacy.

cautions.negative_action: Neglecting to explain rationale for therapy and interventions
cautions.description: Not clarifying purpose behind interventions or making process opaque.
cautions.risk: Undermines trust and collaboration.

cautions.negative_action: Endorsing avoidance, suppression, or denial of distressing emotions
cautions.description: Encouraging patient to suppress, ignore, or avoid emotional or distressing content.
cautions.risk: Blocks emotional processing and genuine healing.

cautions.negative_action: Making premature inferences or interpretations without patient input
cautions.description: Drawing conclusions about symptoms or underlying causes without collaboration or sufficient evidence.
cautions.risk: Leads to errors, reduces alliance quality.

cautions.negative_action: Using non-specific, vague, or unstructured session formats or goals
cautions.description: Skipping agenda-setting or using unclear/unrealistic goal setting.
cautions.risk: Sessions become unfocused, limiting therapeutic progress.

cautions.negative_action: Shaming or blaming for ineffective coping attempts
cautions.description: Criticizing patient for trying but failing to implement helpful strategies.
cautions.risk: Increases defensiveness and disengagement.

cautions.negative_action: Neglecting supervision, reflective practice, or self-care
cautions.description: Ignoring personal burnout or failing to seek feedback or supervision.
cautions.risk: Reduces therapy quality and increases risk of error.

cautions.negative_action: Practicing outside scope of competence
cautions.description: Treating cases beyond professional expertise or legal authority.
cautions.risk: Risks patient safety, legal consequences, and ineffective treatment.

cautions.negative_action: Proceeding with advanced interventions or schema work before basic skills are established
cautions.description: Attempting complex treatments or cognitive restructuring prematurely.
cautions.risk: Patient may disengage or not benefit from therapy.

cautions.negative_action: Rushing assessment or pressing for full disclosure early
cautions.description: Hurrying intake or pushing patients for personal revelations prematurely.
cautions.risk: Increases patient anxiety and diminishes engagement.

cautions.negative_action: Combining medication and CBT without coordination
cautions.description: Implementing both therapies without clarifying roles, rationale, or monitoring effects.
cautions.risk: Confusion regarding treatment impact and reduced efficacy.

cautions.negative_action: Encouraging excessive self-blame or guilt
cautions.description: Promoting harsh internal dialogue or shame during cognitive restructuring.
cautions.risk: Undermines healing and increases depressive symptoms.

cautions.negative_action: Promoting unreliable or anecdotal information
cautions.description: Endorsing non-evidence-based approaches or unverified advice.
cautions.risk: Risks ineffective or harmful outcomes.

cautions.negative_action: Minimizing positive feedback, strengths, or small improvements
cautions.description: Only emphasizing problems, ignoring growth and achievement.
cautions.risk: Decreases motivation and self-efficacy.
